overview_of_class:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / The course explores problems that arise in the planning and management of large-scale CEE systems. We introduce a set of quantitative tools to develop prescriptive models that can be used to address each of the problems. The tools are drawn from decision analysis,dynamic programming, linear and nonlinear programming, etc.

COURSE OBJECTIVES /
1. To encourage the development of a "systems perspective" necessary for the planning and management of large scale civil and environmental engineering systems;
2. To gain experience in formulating and solving a range of civil and environmental engineering problems; and
3. To enable the students to become proficient in the use of commercial software to solve engineering problems.
name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Systems Analysis

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Knowledge of Calculus and Probability. The intended audience for this consists of CEE Juniors and Seniors, and first-year CEE graduate students.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
The focus of the class will be on developing models to address the problems and using commercial software packages to obtain solutions.
* The lectures will focus on the methodological tools and the solution of problems to reinforce the material. The problems discussed will be assigned as group projects as a way to integrate the methodological tools with the use of software.
* Assuming that the course will have 3 meetings/week, I plan to devote 1 session/week to discussion and to teaching the students how to use the software.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
EVALUATION METHOD:

1. 3 Team Projects 30%
2. Best 4 of 6 Homework Assignments 20%
3. Midterm 20%
4. Final 30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The required textbook for the class is Revelle, C.S., Whitlatch, E.E., and Wright, J.R.(2004); Civil and Environmental Systems Engineering; Prentice Hall, 0-13-047822-9.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Other reference texts include:
1. Hillier, F. and Lieberman, G. (1990); Introduction to Operations Research; Fifth Edition, McGraw-Hill.
2. deNeufville, R. (1990); Applied Systems Analysis; McGraw-Hill.
